p: Thus, the chemical nature of C. citratus essential oils may have contributed to its weaker activity since the main constituents are the low toxicity aldehydes citral and neral (70% in content) [ 75], the monoterpene myrcene and the terpenic alcohol geranial [ 75]. On the other hand, R. officinalis, are reach in high toxicity terpenic alcohols such as 1,8-cineole (35.32%), trans-caryophyllene (14.47%), borneol (9.37%), camphor (8.97%), α-pinene (7.9%) and α-thujone (6.42%). Finally, the fact that the primary constituents of G. procumbens oil are very poor in monoterpenoids content [ 76, 77], in which limonene is the most dominant (2.17%), but are very rich in methyl salicylate (96.9%) which possess antimicrobial properties [ 78], may explain the weak bioactivity that was register in most cases.
